Intervention.evidence: high flow (2.9 l · min –1 · m –2 , n = 19) or standard flow (2.4 l · min –1 · m –2 , n = 17)

Objective.evidence: The authors investigated whether an amount higher than their standard blood flow during CPB could improve renal blood flow, the oxygen demand–supply relationship, and function and attenuate tubular injury.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Systemic hemodynamics and renal variables were measured before and during CPB.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 19) or standard flow (2.4 l · min –1 · m –2 , n = 17)

Result_Outcome.evidence: high flow led to a larger increase in systemic oxygen delivery (100 [95% CI, 60 to 141] vs. 31 [1.9 to 65] ml · min –1 · m –2 ]; between-group P < 0.001; effect size Cohen’s dz , 0.59)

Harms.evidence: No perfusion-related adverse events were seen in either group.
